newsitem.title: USA: Dlr stumbles in U.S to end off after hitting highs.
newsitem.headline: Dlr stumbles in U.S to end off after hitting highs.

text.p: The dollar seesawed Wednesday, powering to a 46-month high against the yen and a 30-month high versus the mark before succumbing to profit-taking to close mostly lower.
Propelling the dollar's ascent was a recent string of healthy U.S. economic data and the market's desire to push the dollar above 1.60 marks, a key level not seen since July 1994.
"The psychological level of 1.60 marks was a magnet to the market," said Seth Garrett, chief dealer at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Also, public concern over the health of Russian president Boris Yeltsin aided the dollar, dealers said.

Chief Kremlin doctor Sergei Mironov said Wednesday that Yeltsin had a "fairly serious illness" and should stay in the hospital until the end of the week because of the risk of complication in his pneumonia.
Traders bought dollars as a currency of refuge. Signs of political turmoil in Russia typically weaken the mark because of the close economic ties between Russia and Germany.
The dollar made its sixth consecutive high in as many trading days at 1.60 marks.
Its inability to push past that level, along with significant early losses in U.S. stocks and bonds, caused dealers to lock in profits by selling dollars.

"On New Year's Eve, we were at 1.5380 marks and we went up to 1.60 today -- that is six pfennigs up without any retracement," said Hans Boman, chief spot dealer at Swedbank. "But I don't think this retracement will last for long."

The dollar closed lower at 1.5855/65 marks compared to 1.5970/80 at Wednesday's open. After hitting a 31-month high against the Swiss franc at 1.3808, the dollar closed down at 1.3700/10 from 1.3765/75.
Against the yen, the dollar closed at 116.85/90, below its 117.47 European high and 117.35/40 open.
Dealers said a Japanese newspaper report, which quoted a Bank of Japan official as saying the central bank will maintain its low interest rate policy for the time being, hurt the yen.
The British pound gained against the dollar after the Office for National Statistics reported surprisingly strong December jobs data in the United Kingdom.
"Sterling moved higher after the better-than-expected employment numbers today," said Christian Laland, a trader at Norwest Bank in Minneapolis.

The monthly monetary meeting between UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke and Bank of England Governor Eddie George was held Wednesday, but any decision regarding a speculated rise in interest rates is unlikely to become known until Thursday, traders said.
Higher U.K. rates would make pound-denominated instruments more attractive to foreign investors.
Sterling ended higher at $1.6830/40 versus $1.6730/40 at Wednesday's open.
In other trade, the dollar fell to Canadian $1.3413/18 from C$1.3457/62. The Australian dollar inched lower to $0.7760/65 from $0.7763/68.
